utterances: Trisha Brown won many awards.
In 1991, she was the first female choreographer to get a MacArthur Genius Grant.
She's also a member of the Hall of Fame at the National Museum of Dance.
Now an improbable soap opera.
Well, Robben and Pilchard were a hot pair for a while.
And unfortunately Robben left Pilchard and is now paired with our dominant male, Preston.
This is All My Penguins.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
All My Penguins is a blog.
It's written by Sunny Nelson, bird curator at Chicago's Lincoln Park Zoo.
Last year the zoo welcomed a new colony of African penguins.
Everybody was very excited.
So even the folks that worked here wanted to find out how the new penguins were acclimating, who they were.
So she began to send out weekly notes about them.
This summer the updates turn into a full-blown blog because there was so much drama among the 15 penguins in the colony.
They all have nicknames, by the way.
Robben and Pilchard whom we heard about having a fling - well, Robben's nickname is The Main Squeeze.
Pilchard's known as The Salty One.
Salty because Robben left him.
So for a while, Pilchard was kind of roaming around and peeking his head in the nest box that Robben was in with her new mate and trying to kind of get her back.
And I think he's finally maybe given up a little bit.
Now he's hanging out with his new friend, Phil.
You need a good friend after a tough breakup.
Mating penguins usually stay together for years.
You know, we normally hear about the birds being monogamous in the wild, monogamous in other areas.
And our colony's new, so it makes sense that they're trying to get to know each other and hanging out with each other.
But I really was surprised by all of the nest box switches and the new pairs that were being created day to day.
Sunny Nelson posts a new chapter of All My Penguins every two weeks on the Lincoln Park Zoo website.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
One more word you'll hear this week - well, it's really an acronym, but it is so familiar, we're going to call it a word - NAFTA, the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Later this week, the Trump administration will kick off its talks to renegotiate NAFTA with Canada and Mexico.
And despite Trump's fiery rhetoric about NAFTA on the campaign trail, it appears the administration has backed away from throwing out the 23-year-old trade deal or even majorly overhauling it.
We're joined now by NPR's Chris Arnold.
Hi, Chris.
Hey, Stacey.
So, Chris, let's go back to the days of the campaign.
Here is what President Trump had to say about NAFTA back then.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
NAFTA was the worst deal ever made in the history of the world.
It was a one-way highway out of the United States.
The worst deal in the history of the world (laughter).
Right.
I mean, there is definitely no hyperbole or exaggeration going on there whatsoever.
That is a bad deal.
Yes.
But as you know, I mean, look, candidate Trump back then was resonating with voters who were upset about the decline in manufacturing jobs.
And he was tapping into some very real frustrations.
And, certainly, many Americans who've been affected by global trade and seen their friends or themselves lose jobs - I mean, they see these trade deals as the bad guys stealing American jobs.
So what do we actually expect to happen when NAFTA renegotiations start on Wednesday?
Well, what we don't expect to see is what happened to the TPP - right?
- the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Now, similarly on the campaign, President Trump - when he was candidate Trump - was bashing the TPP.
And when he got elected, he followed through on his pledge to scuttle it.
Now, this is very different.
NAFTA is not going to go away.
What we're seeing here is some more tweaking around the margins.
There's something called rules of origin, which has to do with what percentage of a product has to be made in either Mexico or the U.S.
or Canada.
They're going to be looking to tweak that.
There's some updating of NAFTA, which everybody pretty much agrees needs to happen in part because, look, I mean, technologies, e-commerce, there's issues about data security.
I mean, stuff that just nobody contemplated 30 years ago when NAFTA was created.
We have to write some of that stuff into it.
And there's some labor and environmental regulations.
Basically, it's easier to kind of skirt regulations in Mexico, and the U.S.
says, well, that's not fair.
But as far as tearing up NAFTA or drastically changing it, it looks like that is not going to happen.
Well, why not?
The Trump administration did scrap the TPP, so why not get rid of NAFTA?
President-elect Donald Trump has recommended the United Kingdom choose someone he likes to be ambassador to the U.S., Nigel Farage.
That's the leader of the U.K.'s Independence Party.
He championed Britain's exit from the European Union.
And Trump has tweeted he would do a great job as ambassador.
The U.K.'s prime minister's office is not amused.
For more on this diplomatic story, we turn to Frank Langfitt in London.
Hey there, Frank.
Hey, Audie.
How are you doing?
Good.
So we mentioned, obviously, countries choose their own ambassadors.
So how is this going down in London?
Well, I think right now, given the votes that we've just had, I don't see the numbers there, either for getting past the filibuster in the Senate, and especially getting past a presidential veto.
But I think that we are going to see lot of action, especially on the supplemental funding request for Iraq of $100 billion that's coming up in the next few weeks.
There are going to be many attempts to attach strings to that.
NPR's congressional correspondent David Welna.
David, thanks a lot.
You're welcome, Liane.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Lynn Neary in Washington, sitting in for Neal Conan.

There was once a time when the unexpected happened on radio and perhaps no one remembers that time as well as Studs Terkel, who began his career in radio with the weekly music program called ""The Wax Museum."" Terkel got to play whatever he wanted, from opera to jazz to folk, an eclectic mix that reflected
no one's taste but his own.
He went on to become well known for his oral histories of everyday life and the unsung hero.
Terkel chronicled the trials and tribulations of ordinary men and women in his book ""Working,"" and their hopes and disappointments in ""American Dreams: Lost and Found.
Now at the age of 93, he's come full circle to his early love of music and the radio show that started his conversation with America.

In his latest book, ""And All They Sang: Adventures of an Eclectic Disc Jockey,"" he's collected interviews that reflect his diverse taste in music ranging from opera to jazz, classical to the blues, as well as folk and rock.
And Studs Terkel joins me now in Studio 3A.
Welcome.
So good to have you.
Why, thank you very much, Lynn.
If you have a question for Studs Terkel, join the conversation.
Our number here in Washington is (800) 989-8255; that's (800) 989-TALK.
And our e-mail address is totn@npr.org.

You know, I have to say, when I was reading the introduction to your book and you were describing your early days in radio, it made me nostalgic for a time when, you know, radio was the kind of place where anything could happen.
Just what was it like when you were first starting out?
Well, I first started out as a gangster in radio soap operas.
Uh-huh.
Chicago had more radio soap operas than New York and Hollywood put together.
And they all were the same.
You know, ""Guiding Light"" was about a young minister; ""Woman in White"" obviously about a young nurse.
Yeah.
And the scripts were all--and the gangsters were all the same, Chicago gangsters.
And there were three, usually three: the bright one, the middle one and the dumb one.
I was always the dumb one.
So I spoke in...
Can you still do the voice?
Can you still...
What's that?
